subject: Career
title: Executive Presence: The Perception of Power
description: A quick win: understand Executive Presence: The Perception of Power.

hook.text: Two people say the same thing. One is ignored. The other commands attention. The difference? Executive presence.

buildup.text: Executive presence is how you're perceived: your composure, communication clarity, and gravitas under pressure.

discovery.text: Sylvia Ann Hewlett's research identified three pillars: gravitas (67%), communication (28%), and appearance (5%).

twist.text: Gravitas isn't about being loud. It's about staying calm in chaos, showing decisiveness, and projecting confidence.

climax.text: Develop presence: pause before speaking, eliminate filler words, maintain eye contact, and own your space.

punchline.text: Presence isn't about being seen. It's about being remembered.

quiz.question: What is the most important pillar of executive presence according to Hewlett?
